title: EB-rMAP Prior with a Time-to-Event Endpoint
text: data 10 oncology studies come Roychoudhury Neueuschwander (2020) [2]. study, four-year follow-period partitioned 12 intervals, number events total exposure (follow-) time years recorded. illustration purposes, first 9 trials regarded historical trials, 10th trial considered current trial. full data displayed Appendix. aggregate data year 0 1.5 implement EB-rMAP method log hazard rates. Aggregated Data Year 1.5 random effect meta-analysis yields point estimate 0.38, 95% CI (0.282, 0.510).

title: EB-rMAP Prior with a Time-to-Event Endpoint
text: MAP prior derived using RBesT::gMAP command via Poisson regression. critical specify log total exposure offset model. use specifications section 4 Zhang et al. [1]: \(N(0,10^2)\) hyper-prior overall mean \(HN(0.5)\) hyper-prior exchangeability parameter \(\tau\). MAP prior approximated mixture two Gamma distributions (mean number observations, mn parameterization). vague prior construct robust MAP prior \(Gamma(0.38,1)\), mean meta-analysis effective sample size 1. Suppose designing new single arm trial, augmented historical data via robust MAP prior. projected total exposure current trial 117.6 years. Note various software packages may facilitate estimating quantity via simulation, EAST simtrial package. examine behavior EB-rMAP weight correspoding \(\gamma =\) 0.85, 0.9 0.95 respectively.  can immediately see choice \(\gamma=0.95\) might stringent, weight close 1 even observed hazard rate current trial close historical mean hazard rate. initial screen, \(\gamma=0.9\) 0.85 appear reasonable choices. recommend evaluation via simulation studies real applications. illustration purposes, proceed \(\gamma=0.9\). Suppose observe 32 events new trial, corresponding \(w_{EB}\) 0.5. can construct rMAP prior empirical Bayes weight, derive posterior distribution. Bayesian estimation inference based posterior distribution, also weighted mixture Gamma distributions.
code: histdt <- adt[1:9,]  map_mcmc <- gMAP(NEvent ~ 1 + offset(log(TotExp)) | Trial, data = histdt, family = poisson,                   tau.dist = "HalfNormal", tau.prior = cbind(0, 0.5),                  beta.prior=cbind(0, 10)) (map_hat <- automixfit(map_mcmc)) #> EM for Gamma Mixture Model #> Log-Likelihood = 1447.221 #>  #> Univariate Gamma mixture #> Mixture Components: #>   comp1      comp2      #> w  0.8244201  0.1755799 #> a  7.9655739  2.3129948 #> b 21.3824889  3.7639130  (vague_prior <- mixgamma(c(1, 0.38, 1), param = "mn")) #> Univariate Gamma mixture #> Mixture Components: #>   comp1 #> w 1.00  #> a 0.38  #> b 1.00 y_range <- c(0, 50) n <- 117.6  obj1 <- EB_rMAP(map_hat, vague_prior, 0.85, n, y_range) obj2 <- EB_rMAP(map_hat, vague_prior, 0.9, n, y_range) obj3 <- EB_rMAP(map_hat, vague_prior, 0.95, n, y_range)  plotdt1 <- obj1$wdt %>% mutate(Gamma=obj1$ppp_cut) plotdt2 <- obj2$wdt %>% mutate(Gamma=obj2$ppp_cut) plotdt3 <- obj3$wdt %>% mutate(Gamma=obj3$ppp_cut) plotdt <- rbind(plotdt1, plotdt2, plotdt3) plotdt %>%    ggplot(aes(x=y, y = w_eb, color=factor(Gamma))) + geom_line(size=1) +   xlab("Observed Number of Events") + ylab("EB-rMAP Weight") + theme_bw() +   geom_vline(xintercept=0.38*n, linetype="dashed") +   scale_color_discrete(name="Gamma") #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead. wEB(obj2, 32) #> [1] 0.5 rmap <- robustify(map_hat, weight=0.5, mean=0.38, n=1) (postmix_rmap <- postmix(rmap, n = adt$TotExp[10] , m = adt$NEvent[10]/adt$TotExp[10])) #> Univariate Gamma mixture #> Mixture Components: #>   comp1        comp2        robust       #> w   0.70689137   0.06482092   0.22828771 #> a  39.96557392  34.31299476  32.38000000 #> b 138.98248889 121.36391299 118.60000000

title: EB-rMAP Prior with a Time-to-Event Endpoint
text: Number Events Total Exposure (Years)
code: rdt %>% kbl(caption="Number of Events") %>%    kable_classic(full_width = F, html_font = "Cambria", latex_options = "HOLD_position") Edt %>% kbl(caption="Total Exposure (in Years)") %>%    kable_classic(full_width = F, html_font = "Cambria", latex_options = "HOLD_position")

title: EB-rMAP Prior with a Time-to-Event Endpoint
text: [1] Zhang, H., Shen, Y., Li, J., Ye, H., Chiang, AY. (2023+). Adaptively Leveraging External Data Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior Using Empirical Bayes. [2] Roychoudhury, S., Neuenschwander, B. (2020). Bayesian leveraging historical control data clinical trial time--event en Statistics Medicine, 39(7), 984-995.

what: Historical Data and the MAP Prior
title: EB-rMAP Prior with a Normal Endpoint
text: historical data construct MAP prior dataset crohn RBesT package [1]. data contain six historical trials moderate severe Crohn’s disease. normal endpoint change baseline Crohn’s Disease Activity Index (CDAI) week 6, smaller negative value indicates better response. common standard deviation endpoint \(\sigma\) fixed 88. random effect meta-analysis yields point estimate -50 mean response, 95% confidence interval (-61.7, -38.1). MAP prior derived using RBesT::gMAP command, subsequently approximated mixture three conjugate normal distributions RBesT::automixfit command. vauge prior construct robust MAP prior normal distribution mean -50 effective sample size 1. can specified using mn parameterization RBesT::mixnorm. Note hyper-parameters automatically converted ms parameterization corresponding mean standard deviation. detailed specifications, refer Section 3.1 Zhang et al. [2]
code: library(RBesT) library(tidyverse) library(EBrmap)  dt <- RBesT::crohn sigma <- 88 dt$se_yh <- sigma/sqrt(dt$n) kableExtra::kable(dt) set.seed(712) map_mcmc <- gMAP(cbind(y, se_yh) ~ 1 | study,                  weight = n,                  data=dt,                  family=gaussian,                  beta.prior=cbind(0, sigma),                  tau.dist="HalfNormal",tau.prior=cbind(0,sigma/2)) map_hat <- automixfit(map_mcmc) sigma(map_hat) <- sigma  vague_prior <- mixnorm(c(1, -50, 1), sigma=sigma, param="mn")  print(map_hat) #> EM for Normal Mixture Model #> Log-Likelihood = -17266.18 #>  #> Univariate normal mixture #> Reference scale: 88 #> Mixture Components: #>   comp1        comp2        comp3        comp4        #> w   0.48262610   0.41389189   0.06790148   0.03558052 #> m -46.68513756 -51.27537075 -63.24087734 -53.49794772 #> s   7.85276132  24.99653345   7.81928574  53.01822291 print(vague_prior) #> Univariate normal mixture #> Reference scale: 88 #> Mixture Components: #>   comp1 #> w   1   #> m -50   #> s  88

title: EB-rMAP Prior with a Normal Endpoint
text: design current two-arm trial sample sizes control treatment arms respectively \(n_C=50\) \(n_T=100\). general principle evaluate EB-rMAP weight \(w_{EB}\) within reasonably wide range observed mean response \(\bar{y}_C\). case study, set range -80 -20, even wider 95% confidence interval meta analysis, thus yield comprehensive view behavior \(w_{EB}\) across various scenarios. first set \(\gamma\) 0.85 plot. EB_rMAP function implements EB-rMAP prior method.  order tune EB-rMAP prior method, helpful overlay multiple plots \(w_{EB}\) corresponding different \(\gamma\)s plot. can easily done creating multiple EB-rMAP objects minimal data manipulation. example, also consider \(\gamma=\) 0.7, 0.8 0.9. vertical dashed line -49.9 plot represents point estimate historical mean response meta-analysis.  generated plot useful tool conduct initial screen \(\gamma\) value. example, \(\gamma\) 0.7 might overly aggressive still considerable amount borrowing (\(w_{EB}=0.54\)) observed mean response \(\bar{y}_C = -62\) outside 95% meta-analysis confidence interval. hand, one argue \(\gamma\) 0.9 might conservative. illustration purposes, choose \(\gamma=0.85\). practice, initial set \(\gamma\) values determined, performances confirmed via simulations order select \(\gamma\) value yields robust performance.
code: obj1 <- EB_rMAP(map_hat, vague_prior, ppp_cut=0.85, n=100, y_range=c(-80, -20)) plot(obj1) obj2 <- EB_rMAP(map_hat, vague_prior, ppp_cut=0.7, n=100, y_range=c(-80, -20)) obj3 <- EB_rMAP(map_hat, vague_prior, ppp_cut=0.8, n=100, y_range=c(-80, -20)) obj4 <- EB_rMAP(map_hat, vague_prior, ppp_cut=0.9, n=100, y_range=c(-80, -20))  plotdt1 <- obj1$wdt %>% mutate(Gamma=obj1$ppp_cut) plotdt2 <- obj2$wdt %>% mutate(Gamma=obj2$ppp_cut) plotdt3 <- obj3$wdt %>% mutate(Gamma=obj3$ppp_cut) plotdt4 <- obj4$wdt %>% mutate(Gamma=obj4$ppp_cut) plotdt <- rbind(plotdt1, plotdt2, plotdt3, plotdt4) plotdt %>%    ggplot(aes(x=y, y = w_eb, color=factor(Gamma))) + geom_line(size=1) + geom_vline(xintercept=-49.9, linetype="dashed") +   xlab("Observed Mean Response") + ylab("EB-rMAP Weight") + theme_bw() +    scale_color_discrete(name="Gamma") #> Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0. #> ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

what: Inference with Observed Current Trial Data
title: EB-rMAP Prior with a Normal Endpoint
text: Bayesian inference based posterior probabilities can drawn new trial concluded mean responses \(\bar{y}_C\) \(\bar{y}_T\) observed. Suppose \(\bar{y}_C\) \(\bar{y}_T\) -53 -80, respectively. wEB function returns EB-rMAP weight \(w_{EB}\) corresponding observed mean response \(\bar{y}_C\). weight used build robust MAP prior control mean responses. draw sample size 20,000 posterior distribution robust MAP prior. treatment arm current trial augmented historical data. therefore use vague prior rMAP prior mean response, also draw posterior sample size 20,000. Finally, decision rule claim trial success \(Pr(\theta_T-\theta_C<0|data)>0.95\). can evaluated following codes. Since posterior probability 0.987 exceeds cutoff 0.95, trial success can called.
code: (w <- wEB(obj1, -53)) #> [1] 0.11  (rmap_c <- robustify(map_hat, weight = w, mean = -50, n=1, sigma = sigma)) #> Univariate normal mixture #> Reference scale: 88 #> Mixture Components: #>   comp1        comp2        comp3        comp4        robust       #> w   0.42953723   0.36836378   0.06043232   0.03166666   0.11000000 #> m -46.68513756 -51.27537075 -63.24087734 -53.49794772 -50.00000000 #> s   7.85276132  24.99653345   7.81928574  53.01822291  88.00000000 (postmix_rmap_c <- postmix(rmap_c, n = 50, m = -53)) #> Using default prior reference scale 88 #> Univariate normal mixture #> Reference scale: 88 #> Mixture Components: #>   comp1        comp2        comp3        comp4        robust       #> w   0.59380430   0.29368965   0.07194565   0.01296934   0.02759105 #> m -48.48342373 -52.65742172 -60.34236670 -53.02600372 -52.94117647 #> s   6.64117806  11.14068322   6.62089251  12.11577029  12.32246474 post_rmap_c <- rmix(mix = postmix_rmap_c, n = 20000) prior_t <- mixnorm(c(1, -50, 1), sigma=sigma, param="mn") postmix_t <- postmix(prior_t, n = 100, m = -80) #> Using default prior reference scale 88 post_t <- rmix(mix = postmix_t, n = 20000) diff_sample <- post_t - post_rmap_c mean(diff_sample < 0) #> [1] 0.9869

what: Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior with Empirical Bayes
title: Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior with Empirical Bayes
text: package implements empirical Bayes robust meta-analytical-predictive (EB-rMAP) prior Zhang et al. (2023+) [1]. can install package GitHub : See vignettes use cases.

title: Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior with Empirical Bayes
text: [1] Zhang, H., Shen, Y., Li, J., Ye, H., Chiang, AY. (2023+). Adaptively Leveraging External Data Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior Using Empirical Bayes.

what: Empirical Bayes Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior — EB_rMAP
title: Empirical Bayes Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior — EB_rMAP
text: Implement empirical Bayes robust meta-analytical-predictive (EB-rMAP) prior outcomes distributions including binomial, normal (known standard deviation) Poisson.

title: Empirical Bayes Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior — EB_rMAP
code: EB_rMAP(map_obj, vague_prior, ppp_cut, n, y_range = NA, nbreak = 100)

title: Empirical Bayes Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior — EB_rMAP
text: map_obj mixture conjugate priors approximating MAP prior, derived *RBesT* package. vague_prior vague prior form robust MAP prior, must class `map_obj`. ppp_cut scalar cutoff prior predictive p value. n Current trial sample size: number subjects binary normal endpoints; total exposure time--event endpoint. y_range vector containing lower upper limits observed response current trial. Required normal time--event endpoints. nbreak number breaks within `y_range`, inclusive lower upper limits. Required normal endpoint. See details. Default 100.

title: Empirical Bayes Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior — EB_rMAP
text: object S3 class "EBrMAP"

title: Empirical Bayes Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior — EB_rMAP
text: discrete outcomes (binomial Poisson), possible outcome values can enumerated thus `nbreak` option needed. Note `y_range` still needed Poisson outcome. normal outcome, interval `y_range` evenly divided `nbreak` breaks. EB-rMAP weight computed break value. Default `nbreak` 100. finer grid can used larger `nbreak` cost computation time.

title: Empirical Bayes Robust Meta-Analytical-Predictive Prior — EB_rMAP
code: if (FALSE) { set.seed(712)  dt <- RBesT::crohn sigma <- 88 dt$se_yh <- sigma/sqrt(dt$n) map_mcmc <- RBesT::gMAP(cbind(y, se_yh) ~ 1 | study, weight = n, data=dt,                     family=gaussian, beta.prior=cbind(0, sigma),                     tau.dist="HalfNormal",tau.prior=cbind(0,sigma/2)) map_hat <- RBesT::automixfit(map_mcmc) sigma(map_hat) <- sigma vague_prior <- RBesT::mixnorm(c(1, -50, 1), sigma=sigma, param="mn")  obj <- EB_rMAP(map_hat, vague_prior, ppp_cut=0.85, n=100, y_range=c(-80, -20)) wEB(obj, -61) plot(obj) }

title: Obtain the EB-rMAP Weight — wEB

title: Obtain the EB-rMAP Weight — wEB
text: `y_obs` binomial Poisson outcomes must integer. case normal outcome, `y_obs` matched closest break `y_range` argument `EB_rMAP` function, whose corresponding EB-rMAP weight returned. Rounding issues may cause error occasionally. case, jittering `y_obs` might help. example, try `wEB(obj, 30.001)` `wEB(obj, 30)` fails.
